Universitaria, Coyoacán, 04510, Ciudad de México, México ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 In memory of Elena Klimova ZrO2-SBA-15 supports were synthesized by chemical grafting and used to prepare NiPt catalysts tested in the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole. ZrO2 loading in the supports was varied (4, 8, and 12 wt% of ZrO2) maintaining the metal loading constant (5 wt% Ni, 1 wt% Pt) with the aim to inquire into the effect of ZrO2 on the characteristics and performance of the NiPt/Zr-SBA-15 catalysts. A simplified reaction mechanism was proposed and kinetic analysis was performed to estimate reaction rate constants and correlate them with characteristics of the active sites. ZrO2-containing catalysts showed a better dispersion of metal nanoparticles than the reference NiPt/SBA-15 due to a stronger metal-support interaction and increased acidity. Both hydrogenation and deoxygenation abilities of the catalysts (rate constants k 1 and k 2 ) improved with zirconia addition. The effect of zirconia was much stronger on the increased deoxygenation of cyclohexyl methyl ether and cyclohexanol to cyclohexane, in line with increasing surface density of acid sites. The hydrogenation ability of the catalysts correlated well with metal dispersion. Thus, the role of zirconia in the NiPt/Zr-SBA-15 catalysts was clarified by using a kinetic approach. The participation of metal and acid sites at different steps of anisole HDO and the reasons of metal-acid synergy in these bifunctional catalysts were demonstrated. The stability of the most active NiPt/8ZrS catalyst was tested in three repeated catalytic cycles. The metallic active sites showed stability in recycling, while the acid active sites were affected by coke deposition or adsorption of organic compounds decreasing selectivity to cyclohexane product. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Anisole Kinetic analysis Bifunctional metal-acid catalysts NiPt Zr-SBA-15 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The increase in population and industrial development has led to an increase in global energy demand. According to the International Energy Agency, since 2010, the energy demand has increased by 1.4 % per year, which has resulted in the challenge of supplying sufficient energy to meet this demand [1]. Nowadays, approximately 76 % of the energy supply comes from fossil fuel derivatives. Nonetheless, reducing fossil fuel consumption is a fundamental matter to be addressed to reduce environmental pollution and climate change. This leads to a transition to cleaner energy sources with less impact on the environment, such as bioenergy. Bioenergy is a type of renewable energy that uses organic matter or biomass to generate heat, electricity, and biofuels [2,3]. Particularly, bio-oil is a quick pyrolysis product of lignocellulosic biomass and is considered a carbon-neutral emission. However, bio-oil has some undesirable characteristics, such as high corrosiveness, thermal instability and high oxygen content, explaining the necessity of the bio-oil upgrading [4]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a process for bio-oil improvement, providing better stability and higher energy density. Additionally, HDO can be used for biofuel production under mild reaction conditions. HDO is carried out catalytically, removing oxygen atoms from organic molecules by reacting with H2 [5]. HDO reactions generally have a complex reaction mechanism comprising several parallel and consecutive reactions, which include hydrogenation of aromatic rings and double bonds and cleavage of Caromatic-O and Caliphatic-O bonds leading to deoxygenation of starting reactants and intermediate compounds. Supported catalysts are widely employed for HDO reactions, where the catalytically active phases: transition or noble metals (Ni, Fe, Co, Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, etc.) or transition metal sulfides, carbides or phosphides (MoS2, Mo2C, Ni2P, etc.) are dispersed on the supports, commonly with acid characteristics [5,6]. Several studies have proposed the use of bifunctional catalysts, where the synergy between the metal and acid active sites results in better selectivity for desired fully hydrogenated and deoxygenated products in the HDO of bio-oil [7]. Bimetallic catalysts, such as the Ni-Pt ones, have demonstrated efficiency in HDO processes because of their enhanced hydrogen adsorption capabilities, which facilitate the hydrogenation steps. Furthermore, the presence of Pt contributed to increased stability by inhibiting the oxidation of Ni active sites and mitigating catalyst sintering [8–10]. Mesoporous silica materials, such as SBA-15, have been extensively utilized as supports owing to their low cost, large specific surface area, and ability to incorporate the active phase within mesopores [11]. In previous works of our group, NiPt catalysts supported on SBA-15 silica were tested in the HDO of anisole, showing high activity for hydrogenation [12–14]. However, pure silica lacks acidity, which is an important feature of bifunctional catalysts for increasing their selectivity for desired products. One of the most common methods for introducing acidity to the silica materials is the incorporation of different acid species, such as TiO2, ZrO2, Al2O3, Nb2O5, etc. [15]. Several studies have demonstrated that the incorporation of ZrO2 into SBA-15 by chemical grafting provides acidity, while preserving the mesoporous structure. The presence of ZrO2 promotes a stronger interaction between the metal active phase and the support, resulting in enhanced metal dispersion and mitigating sintering [16–19]. In summary, research on HDO reactions catalyzed by metals supported on Zr-SBA-15 has shown a synergy between acid and metal components of the catalyst that leads to increased selectivity towards oxygen-free products [20,21]. Also, it has been proven that the Si/Zr ratio affects the activity of the materials. M. Lopez et al. [22] presented the results of the HDO reaction of guaiacol, where the Ni-SBA-15 catalyst showed a 34 % conversion without formation of oxygen free products, while the Ni-Zr-SBA-15 catalyst had 88 % conversion and a 63.5 % selectivity toward cyclohexane. In addition, C. Ochoa-Hernandez et al. [23] concluded that catalysts with higher Zr content resulted in higher conversions, but an adequate metal-support combination is required to promote hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). L. Calzada et al. [15] modified the SBA-15 supports with Ti, Zr, Al and Nb oxides and used them for the preparation of Ni catalysts tested in the HDO of anisole. The highest anisole conversion (98 %) was obtained with the Ni/Zr-SBA-15 catalyst, followed by the Ni/Al-SBA-15 one. Both catalysts showed similar selectivity to cyclohexane (∼ 91 % at 98 % conversion). In the present work, NiPt catalysts supported on SBA-15 materials modified with different contents of ZrO2 were prepared, characterized and tested in HDO of anisole in order to determine the relationship between ZrO2 loading and catalysts’ activity and selectivity in HDO. Kinetic analysis was performed and the reaction rate constants were estimated for a better understanding of the obtained activity and selectivity trends and to correlate them with the results from the characterization of the metal and acid active sites of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of SBA-15 and Zr-SBA-15 supports The mesoporous SBA-15 support was synthesized by the hydrothermal method described by Zhao et al. [24]. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %, Aldrich) was used as the silica source, and triblock Pluronic P123 copolymer EO20-PO70-EO20 (MAV=5800 g/mol, Aldrich) as the templating agent. The typical procedure was as follows: 4 g of P123 copolymer was dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water and stirred for 30 min, then 120 mL of an aqueous 2 M HCl solution were added and the stirring was continued for another 2 h. The obtained solution was heated to 35 °C and TEOS (8.5 g) was added dropwise, keeping the temperature and stirring for 20 h. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave for maturation at 100 °C for 24 h without stirring. The obtained solid product was filtered, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and then dried at room temperature for 24 h. Finally, it was calcined at 550 °C in a static air atmosphere for 6 h (0.8 °C/min ramp) to remove the organic template. The synthesized SBA-15 silica support was denoted as S. The SBA-15 support modified with ZrO2 was prepared by chemical grafting. Zirconium(IV) n-propoxide (70 wt% solution in 1-propanol, Aldrich) was used as the zirconia precursor. Solutions with the amount of precursor required to obtain ZrO2-containing SBA-15 supports with 4, 8, or 12 wt% of ZrO2 were prepared using absolute ethanol (J.T. Baker) as a solvent. 100 mL of solution were used per gram of SBA-15. The SBA-15 support (1 g), previously dried at 100 °C for 24 h, was added to the solution and stirred at room temperature for 2 h in an inert (Ar) atmosphere. After that, the solid material was filtered in vacuum and washed twice with dry ethanol (100 mL per g of support) to remove the unreacted Zr(IV) precursor. The modified supports were dried at room temperature (12 h) and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h (0.8 °C/min ramp) in static air. The ZrO2-modified SBA-15 supports were denoted as xZrS, where x = 4, 8, and 12, corresponding to their respective nominal ZrO2 loadings (wt%). 2.2 Preparation of NiPt catalysts NiPt catalysts with theoretical loadings of 5 wt% Ni and 1 wt% Pt were prepared by incipient wetness co-impregnation of the S and xZrS supports, using aqueous solutions of nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate ((Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, 99 %, Aldrich) and tetraammineplatinum(II) nitrate ([Pt(NH3)4](NO3)2, 99.995 %, Aldrich) precursors. After the impregnation, the catalysts were dried at room temperature for 24 h, then at 100 °C for 12 h (0.8 °C/min ramp), and finally calcined at 500 °C for 2 h (3 °C/min ramp) in a static air atmosphere. The prepared catalysts were labeled as NiPt/respective support. 2.3 Characterization of supports and catalysts The synthesized supports and catalysts were characterized by N2-physisorption, small- and wide-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS), scanning electron microscopy with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM and STEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained with a Micromeritics 3-Flex automatic analyzer at liquid N2 temperature (-197.5 °C). The samples were previously degassed in a Micromeritics SmartPrep Degas System under a N2 flow (20 mL/min) at 270°C for 12 h. Specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method (SBET). The total pore volume (VP) was determined by N2 uptake at a relative pressure P/P0 = 0.99, and pore size distributions were obtained from the adsorption isotherms using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The reported mesopore diameters (DP) were determined as the maxima of the corresponding pore size distributions. The micropore area (Sµ) was estimated using the correlation of t-Harkins & Jura (t-plot method). Powder XRD measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer, using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) and a goniometer speed of 1° (2θ) per min. The XRD patterns of the samples were recorded from 3° to 80° (2θ). This technique was used for the characterization of supports, calcined and reduced catalysts. The small-angle XRD patterns recorded from 0.6° to 5° (2θ) were obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using small divergence and scattering slits of 0.05°. UV–vis DRS spectra of the samples were recorded using a Varian Cary 100 spectrophotometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance integrating sphere attachment for solid samples. Polytetrafluoroethylene was used as a reference material. The powder samples were loaded onto a Teflon cell with a quartz window and measured from 200 to 800 nm at room temperature. The Kubelka-Munk function was calculated from reflectance by F(R) = (1 - R)2/2 R. The chemical composition of materials and elemental mappings were obtained by a SEM-EDS analysis, using a JEOL JSM-5900 LV microscope with OXFORD ISIS equipment. Characterization of metal nanoparticles in the reduced catalysts was performed by TEM and STEM. TEM images were recorded using a JEOL 2010 microscope (1.9 Å resolution at 200 kV). The solids were ultrasonically dispersed in heptane and the suspension was collected on carbon coated grids. For each catalyst, approximately 1000 particles were measured to obtain a relative frequency histogram of the particle size. Scanning-transmission electron microscopy (STEM) in high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) mode was performed in a Cs-corrected JEOL ARM-200F electron microscope located at Laboratorio Universitario de Microscopía Electrónica (LUME-UNAM, RRID:SCR_024400), operated at 200 keV. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was carried out with an Oxford AZtecTEM detector. H2-TPR and NH3-TPD experiments were performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. For H2-TPR experiments, the catalysts were pretreated at 400 °C for 2 h in situ under an Ar stream. Reduction analysis was carried out recording H2 consumption from 40 to 1000 °C, at a heating rate 10 °C/min, under a H2/Ar mixture flow (10:90 v/v, 50 mL/min). For the NH3-TPD analysis, the samples were pretreated at 400 °C for 2 h in situ under an Ar stream. Ammonia adsorption was performed at 120 °C under a flow of NH3/He mixture (10:90 v/v, 20 mL/min) for 30 min. Ammonia desorption was performed from 120 °C to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyses were carried out using an ultra-high vacuum (UHV) system, the Scanning XPS microprobe PHI 5000 VersaProbe II, with an Al Kα monochromatic X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV) with 200 µm beam diameter, and a Multi-Channel Detector (MCD) analyzer. The XPS spectra were obtained at room temperature at 45º to the normal surface in the constant pass energy mode (CAE); survey scans were recorded at E0 = 117.40 eV and high-resolution narrow scans at 11.75 eV. The base pressure in the analyzing chamber was maintained in the order of 5 × 10−8 Pa. Surface of the samples was etched for 5 min with 1 kV Ar+ at 1 µA/mm². The peak positions were referenced to the C band in the C 1 s spectrum at 285.0 eV. The atomic ratio of elements in the surface layers accessible to XPS analysis was calculated from the integrated line intensity of Ni 2p and Pt 4 f and the corresponding atomic sensitivity factors (3.702 for Ni 2p and 6.08 for Pt 4 f). All spectra were processed with the MultiPak PHI software. The XPS analysis deconvolution of spectra were fitted with the Spectral Data Processor program, SDP v 4.1. The recorded spectra were fitted using a Gaussian–Lorentzian combination based on an Offset Shirley background type. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests Prior to the catalytic activity tests, the catalysts were reduced ex situ in a U-shaped glass flow reactor at 400°C for 4 h, under a stream of H2/Ar (70:30 mol:mol) at atmospheric pressure. The hydrodeoxygenation of anisole was performed in a 300 mL stainless steel batch reactor (Parr), with a 0.37 M solution of anisole (Aldrich, 99 %) in hexadecane (Aldrich, 99 %). For each experiment, 50 mL of anisole solution and 0.1 g of reduced catalyst were used. The reactor was filled with 5.0 MPa of hydrogen at room temperature, which gave 6.8 MPa total pressure at the reaction temperature (250 °C). The reactions were performed for 6 h under constant mechanical stirring (500 rpm). To monitor the reaction progress, liquid samples (0.5 mL) were taken and analyzed in an Agilent 6890 gas chromatograph equipped with a FID detector and a non-polar methyl siloxane capillary column HP-1 (50 m × 0.32 mm inner diameter and 0.52 µm film thickness). The products were identified by mass spectroscopy using an Agilent 7890 A GC system equipped with a 5075 C MS detector. The catalytic activity was determined by measuring the anisole concentration at different reaction times. The conversion of anisole (X AN ) was calculated by Eq. 1. (1) X AN = C AN 0 − C AN C AN 0 × 100 % Where C AN0 is the initial anisole concentration (mol L−1) and C AN is the concentration of anisole (mol L−1) at time t (h). Initial reaction rates of formation of cyclohexyl methyl ether, (r CME)0, and cyclohexane, (r CHA)0, were determined as the slopes of the corresponding concentration curves at initial reaction time. The selectivity to cyclohexane (S CHA ) was calculated by Eq. 2. (2) S CHA = C CHA ∑ C products × 100 % Where CCHA is the concentration of cyclohexane (mol L−1) at time t and ∑Cproducts is the sum of the concentrations of all liquid products in the reaction mixture. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supports and catalysts 3.1.1 SEM-EDS The SEM images of S and xZrS supports and their respective elemental mappings are shown in Fig. 1. All the supports exhibited a typical SBA-15 morphology characterized by elongated rod-like fibers, whereas the 12ZrS support displayed agglomerates formed by rice grain-shaped particles. Elemental mapping demonstrated that grafted Zr species were uniformly and homogeneously distributed on the SBA-15 surface. According to the elemental composition of the supports measured by EDS analysis, the ZrO2 loadings were close to the expected theoretical values, namely, they were 4.1 ± 1.0, 7.3 ± 0.8, and 12.7 ± 1.1 wt% of ZrO2 for the 4ZrS, 8ZrS, and 12ZrS supports, respectively. The SEM images of the catalysts ( Fig. 2) did not reveal any morphological differences compared to their respective supports. The experimentally determined Ni and Pt loadings were close to the theoretical values ( Table 1). In addition, Ni and Pt species were uniformly distributed on the supports (Fig. 2). 3.1.2 N2 physisorption The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the supports and calcined catalysts are presented in Fig. 3. The SBA-15 support exhibited a type IV isotherm related to mesoporous materials with an H1 type hysteresis loop, which is characteristic of uniform cylindrical pores (Fig. 3a). The addition of ZrO2 to SBA-15 did not alter the shape of the isotherms; nevertheless, the N2 uptake at P/P0 > 0.65 decreased with increasing ZrO2 loading. This phenomenon can be attributed to the incorporation of ZrO2 into the mesopores. In Fig. 3b, a slight decrease in the pore diameter from 9.0 to 8.1 nm can be observed with the increasing amount of ZrO2 in the supports. For the calcined catalysts, the isotherm shape remained unaltered after Ni and Pt incorporation (Fig. 3c). However, a further decrease in the pore diameter was observed, attributed to the incorporation of the metals on the supports (Fig. 3d). Table 1 presents the textural characteristics of the supports and calcined catalysts. The S BET of the supports decreased from 741 to 538 m2/g as the ZrO2 loading increased. The total pore volume (V P) values followed a similar trend after ZrO2 incorporation into the SBA-15, decreasing from 1.41 to 0.96 cm3/g. The grafted ZrO2 mainly affected the mesopore area (S meso) of the supports, whereas S micro remained unchanged. This indicates that zirconia species are deposited principally on the mesopore walls of the starting SBA-15 support without blocking its micropore structure. Nevertheless, some obstruction of mesopores seems to occur, affecting the S BET values and decreasing pore diameters, as it was observed previously for ZrO2 incorporation on SBA-15 by chemical grafting [25,26]. The calcined NiPt catalysts exhibited lower S BET and Sμ values than their respective supports, attributed to the incorporation of Ni and Pt species. In all cases, S μ decreased by ∼30–40 %, whereas S BET decreased by ∼20–25 %. Both decrements of surface area are much larger than the increase in the materials’ density due to the incorporation of 6 wt% of metals (5 wt% of Ni and 1 wt% of Pt), pointing out to the agglomeration of the deposited metal species blocking the micro- and mesopores of the supports. 3.1.3 X-ray diffraction Fig. 4 presents the small-angle XRD patterns of the synthesized supports and calcined catalysts. For all the samples, three well-resolved signals can be observed at about 0.85, 1.50 and 1.75° (2θ). These signals correspond to (1 0 0), (1 1 0) and (2 0 0) reflections associated with p6mm hexagonal symmetry of the SBA-15 material. The fact that the above peaks could still be clearly observed for the supports with grafted ZrO2 species and calcined NiPt catalysts points out to the preservation of long-order pore arrangement in the xZrS supports and corresponding NiPt catalysts. The structural characteristics of the synthesized xZrS supports and calcined NiPt/xZrS catalysts are presented in Table 2. All the samples showed almost the same d 100 interplanar distance (10.1–10.4 nm) and a 0 unit cell parameter (11.7–12.0 nm). Regarding the pore wall thickness δ, it noticeably increased after the incorporation of zirconia on the SBA-15 surface (from 2.9 to 3.9 nm). It seems that zirconia species cover SBA-15 mesopore walls decreasing pore diameter (Table 1) and increasing pore wall thickness (Table 2). Further incorporation of Ni and Pt species on the xZrS supports did not produce notorious changes in the structural characteristics of the xZrS supports (d 100 and a 0), but it did produce a slight increase in pore wall thickness (0.1 nm for the Zr-containing supports and about 0.3 nm for the SBA-15 silica). Fig. 5 shows wide-angle XRD patterns of xZrS supports and corresponding calcined and reduced NiPt catalysts. The supports exhibited a broad signal between 15 and 35° (2θ), corresponding to the amorphous SiO2 structure of SBA-15. In addition, no signals at 30° (2θ) attributable to tetragonal ZrO2 were observed for the three ZrO2-containing supports (4ZrS, 8ZrS and 12ZrS), indicating high dispersion of grafted zirconia species in the supports (Fig. 5a) [27]. In the XRD patterns of the calcined catalysts (Fig. 5b), peaks at 37.3, 43.3, 62.9, and 75.4° (2θ) were observed, associated with the crystalline phase of NiO (JCPDS-ICDD card No. 47–1049). The average size of NiO crystallites (d NiO) estimated by the Scherrer equation changes from 10.1 nm for the NiPt/S catalyst to 6.9, 7.2 and 6.0 nm for the NiPt/4ZrS, NiPt/8ZrS and NiPt/12ZrS, respectively. The d NiO of the NiPt/xZrS catalysts exhibited lower values compared to that of the NiPt/S reference. This suggests that the incorporation of ZrO2 on the SBA-15 surface enhanced the dispersion of NiO species, resulting in smaller NiO crystallite sizes [19,28]. Fig. 5c shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts after reduction in H2 flow at 400 °C for 4 h. Two new peaks were detected at 44.4 °and 51.6° (2θ), which were associated with the metallic Ni0 crystalline phase (JCPDS-ICDD card No. 01–1258). No peaks corresponding to NiO were detected in the patterns of the reduced catalysts, suggesting that the calcined catalysts were effectively reduced. Additionally, for all calcined and reduced catalysts, no characteristic peaks of Pt were observed, which could be due to the low mass proportion of Pt (1 wt%) in the catalysts and/or to its good dispersion. However, the presence of Pt in the calcined catalysts was corroborated by SEM-EDS analysis (Fig. 2 and Table 1). 3.1.4 UV-Vis DRS Fig. 6 presents the obtained UV-Vis DR spectra of the supports and calcined catalysts. The band located at 230 nm corresponds to SBA-15 [29]. The intensity of this band decreases with increasing ZrO2 loading in the xZrS supports. The signals observed in the DR spectrum of the 12ZrS support at 248 and 280 nm were attributed to ZrO2 species, namely, to the ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) from O2– to Zr4+ of ZrO2 with an octahedral coordination state, which is associated with the Zr-O-Zr linkages of well-dispersed ZrO2 nanoparticles on the SBA-15 surface (Fig. 6a) [17,30]. For the supports with lower ZrO2 loadings (4ZrS and 8ZrS), the signals at 248 and 280 nm are much less notorious indicating the presence of better dispersed octahedrally-coordinated ZrO2 species [31]. Therefore, an increase in ZrO2 loading to values larger than 8 wt% ZrO2 is accompanied by zirconia agglomeration on the SBA-15 surface with formation of small zirconia domains with Zr-O-Zr linkages. On the other hand, the presence of isolated ZrO2 species in tetrahedral coordination was not observed due to the absence of a signal at about 200 nm characteristic of these species [32]. For the calcined NiPt catalysts (Fig. 6b), the broad band located between 200 and 350 nm is attributed to the LMCT from 2p orbitals of O2– to Ni2+ in octahedral coordination. This transition located at 260 nm can be related to NiO species of small particle sizes, whereas the red-shifted band at 290 nm can be associated with larger NiO nanoparticles. In addition, two other observable bands at 420 and 725 nm were attributed to d-d transitions of NiO in octahedral coordination [33]. No signals attributable to Ni2+ species in tetrahedral coordination or to any kind of Pt species were detected in the spectra of the calcined catalysts. From UV-Vis DR spectra of the calcined catalysts, the band gap energies (E g ) were estimated using the Tauc plot method [34]. The NiPt/4ZrS and NiPt/8ZrS catalysts exhibited higher E g values (near 3.75–3.76 eV) compared to those of NiPt/S (3.67 eV) and NiPt/12ZrS (3.64 eV). This result suggests a better dispersion of NiO nanoparticles in the NiPt catalysts supported on xZrS materials with intermediate ZrO2 loadings (NiPt/4ZrS and NiPt/8ZrS catalysts). 3.1.5 H2-TPR The reduction profiles of the NiPt/xZrS catalysts are shown in Fig. 7a. All catalysts exhibited the main reduction peak at a low-temperature region between 200 and 350 °C attributed to the reduction of Ni2+ oxide to metallic Ni0. The maximum of this peak changes from 293 °C to 312–324 °C with the incorporation of zirconia to the SBA-15 support, indicating a slight increase in the difficulty of the reduction of NiO in the ZrO2-containing catalysts due to a stronger metal-support interaction. The NiPt/12ZrS catalyst also exhibited a small shoulder at higher temperature (445 °C), which can be ascribed to the reduction of Ni2+ species in stronger interaction with the 12ZrS support with the highest ZrO2 loading. Probably, these species are located inside the support’s mesopores forming Ni-O-Zr bonds [31]. Additionally, the very low-intensity shoulder at ∼200 °C in all thermograms could be attributed to the decomposition of the residual Ni(NO3)2 precursor [31]. The majority of the NiO species in the calcined NiPt catalysts were reduced at low temperatures (below 400 °C used for the reduction of the catalysts prior to the catalytic activity tests), which can be attributed to the presence of Pt facilitating Ni2+ reduction due to easy hydrogen activation. For comparison, the H2-TPR profiles of the monometallic Ni and bimetallic NiPt catalysts (Ni/12ZrS and NiPt/12ZrS) are shown in Fig. 7b, where the effect of Pt addition on the NiO reduction temperature can be clearly seen. The degrees of reduction (α) for the catalysts were calculated based on the real metal loadings and experimental hydrogen consumption. These values indicate that the NiO species were almost completely reduced in the NiPt/8ZrS and NiPt/12ZrS catalysts (α = 0.98 and 0.99, respectively), while for the NiPt/4ZrS and NiPt/S catalysts these values were slightly lower (α = 0.96–0.95). 3.1.6 NH3-TPD The acid characteristics of the calcined catalysts were determined by NH3-TPD, and the results are presented in Fig. 8 and Table 3. The intensity of the NH3 desorption signals in the profiles on the NiPt catalysts notoriously increased with increasing zirconia loadings (Fig. 8a). This was expected, considering that the SBA-15 silica is almost neutral and the acidity of the supports and catalysts is due to the grafted ZrO2, which provides Lewis acidity through the formation of Zr(OSi)3OH surface species [35]. Additionally, some acidity could be expected in the calcined catalysts from the deposited NiO and Pt species [36]. Three overlapping signals were clearly observed in the ammonia desorption thermograms of the calcined catalysts at ∼185, 290, and 350–375 °C (Fig. 8a). The latter signal shifted to higher temperatures (360, 365 and 375 °C) as the amount of ZrO2 increased from 4 to 8 and 12 wt%, respectively, indicating an increase in the strength of the acid sites. The results from the quantitative analysis of the acidity of the calcined catalysts are presented in Table 3. The acid sites were divided into weak, medium-strength, and strong acid sites, according to the temperatures of ammonia desorption. For the quantification of acid sites of different strengths, the obtained NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts were deconvoluted into four Gaussian curves as shown in Fig. 8b. The most intense fitted peak with maximum at ∼185 °C was attributed to weak acid sites, the next two peaks with maxima at 260–290 °C and 330–370 °C to the medium strength acid sites and the low-intensity signal located at ∼490 °C to strong acid sites, respectively. The amount of acid sites of different strengths was obtained by integrating the area below the fitted peaks. The total amount of acid sites increased with increasing zirconia loading from 69 to 531 µmol NH3/g for the NiPt/S to NiPt/12ZrS catalysts, respectively (Table 3). The acid sites present in all the calcined catalysts were predominantly weak and medium-strength acid sites, with a very low amount of strong acid sites. The surface density of acid sites is also shown in Table 3, where more than a 10-fold increase can be observed with the incorporation of 12 wt% of zirconia on the SBA-15 surface. Among all the catalysts, the NiPt/12ZrS presents the most acidity, which is essential for HDO reactions with bifunctional metal-acid catalysts. 3.1.7 XPS characterization of supports and catalysts XPS analysis of the oxidized NiPt catalysts was conducted to elucidate the electronic states and chemical composition of the catalyst surface. Fig. 9 presents the XPS spectra for the Ni 2p, Ni 3p, Pt 4 f, Si 2p, and Zr 3d core levels of the NiPt catalyst supported on SBA-15 and Zr-grafted SBA-15 supports. For the NiPt/S catalyst (Fig. 9a), the two principal chemical spin states of Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of the Ni2+ in the NiO nanoparticles were identified at binding energies of 854.6 eV and 872.6 eV, respectively, with their corresponding shake-up satellite peaks observed at 861.5 eV and 880.1 eV. The signal of Ni 3p located at 67.6 eV and its satellite at 72.0 eV were also observed, confirming the presence of Ni2+ species in the NiPt/S catalyst. No appreciable shift in the positions of the Ni 2p and 3p signals compared to unsupported NiO was observed [37], indicating that the interaction of NiO with pure silica SBA-15 support is very weak. For the calcined NiPt/12ZrS catalyst (Fig. 9a), a considerable shift of about 1 eV in the positions of the characteristic signals of the Ni2+ of the nickel oxide in the Ni 2p and Ni 3p core levels was observed compared to those of the NiPt/S catalyst. This shift to higher binding energies can be attributed to the presence of ZrO2 species on the surface of the 12ZrS support, and to a strong interaction between the Ni and the Zr oxide species in the NiPt/12ZrS catalyst. This result is in line with the TPR observations, where reduction of the NiO oxide species in the NiPt/12ZrS catalyst occurs at higher temperature than in the NiPt/S analog due to a stronger interaction of Ni oxide species with the zirconia-containing support (Fig. 7a). In the Pt 4 f spectra of the oxidized NiPt/S catalyst (Fig. 9a), two distinct species of Pt were identified. The peaks at 71.1 and 74.5 eV correspond to Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2, respectively, of the metallic Pt0. In addition, the peaks at 72.8 and 76.2 eV of Pt 4 f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2, respectively, are attributed to the oxidized surface Pt2+ species, such as in Pt(II) oxide, associated with Pt interacting with the oxygen of the NiO and SiO2 support, forming Pt-O-Ni and Pt-O-Si moieties [13]. Addition of zirconia species on the surface of the S support did not exhibit any changes in the positions of the Pt 4f signals of the NiPt/12ZrS catalyst with respect to the NiPt/S catalyst without zirconia. It seems that the electronic environment of the Pt species was not affected by the interaction with ZrO2 on the support’s surface. Fig. 9b illustrates the Si 2p core level for the S and 12ZrS supports and corresponding NiPt catalysts. For the S support, the signal at 103.3 eV corresponds to the Si-O-Si bonds of the amorphous silica [38]. No shift in the position of this signal was observed for the NiPt/S catalyst in comparison to the S support, confirming the weak interaction between the deposited NiO and Pt species and the silica support. For the 12ZrS support, in addition to the Si 2p core level signal at 103.3 eV, a new signal was detected at a lower binding energies (102.4 eV), which could be due to the formation of covalent Si-O-Zr bonds [38–40]. This confirms the incorporation of zirconia species on the pore walls of SBA-15 silica. In the case of the NiPt/12ZrS catalyst, the signal corresponding to the Si-O-Zr bonds was observed at 102.1 eV due to the interaction between Ni and Zr. The Zr 3d core level signals of the 12ZrS support and NiPt/12ZrS catalyst are presented in Fig. 9b. The 12ZrS support exhibits a broad signal, attributed to the chemical spin states of Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 from two distinct Zr4+ species. The signals identified at binding energies of 182.3 and 184.7 eV are associated with the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 spin states, respectively, of Zr-O-Zr bonds in ZrO2 [38]. Other two signals located at higher binding energies of 182.9 eV and 185.3 eV can be attributed to the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 spin states, respectively, of covalent Zr-O-Si bonds formed during zirconia grafting on the silica surface. The shift to higher binding energies is due to the higher electronegativity of Si atoms compared to that of Zr atoms, resulting in electron transfer from Zr to Si [38,40]. The above signals of Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 spin states revealed that two types of zirconia species are present on the surface of the 12ZrS support: some small ZrO2 clusters not detected by the wide-angle XRD characterization and isolated ZrO2 species grafted on the SBA-15 surface by covalent Zr-O-Si bonds. For the NiPt/12ZrS catalyst the signal of Zr-O-Si bonds remained practically unchanged, whereas the signals from the Zr-O-Zr bonds slightly shifted to lower binding energies (∼0.2 eV) due to the interaction of ZrO2 species with deposited NiO [41]. Finally, the surface atomic ratio of Ni:Pt atoms was determined for the catalysts characterized by XPS. The Ni:Pt values were 17.5 for the NiPt/S catalyst and 16.9 for the NiPt/12ZrS. These results are close to the bulk molar ratios of Ni:Pt estimated from the SEM-EDS characterization of calcined catalysts (Table 1), which were 16.0 for the NiPt /S and 17.9 for the NiPt/12ZrS. A good agreement between both estimations indicates that Ni and Pt atoms are distributed almost homogeneously on the surface and in the bulk of bimetallic nanoparticles. 3.1.8 HAADF-STEM and TEM characterization of supports and catalysts HAADF-STEM was utilized to inquire more into the distribution and dispersion of zirconia species in the xZrS supports. Results obtained for the 12ZrS support with the highest zirconia loading (12.7 wt%, Table 1) are shown in Fig. 10. Elemental mapping revealed that the grafted zirconium was uniformly distributed on the SBA-15 support. The differences in contrast in the HAADF images were attributed to the differences in atomic numbers between silicon (Z = 14) and zirconium (Z = 40). No ZrO2 crystals or agglomerates were detected in the images of the 12ZrS support confirming results obtained previously by wide-angle XRD and UV-Vis DRS. The calcined and reduced NiPt/12ZrS catalysts were also characterized by HAADF STEM analysis offering a valuable insight into the structure, composition and distribution of metal nanoparticles ( Fig. 11). The bright spots observed in the HAADF STEM images correspond to metal nanoparticles. At atomic resolution, the distinction between Pt (Z = 78) and Ni (Z = 28) is easily noticeable due to the difference in Z contrast between these two elements, indicating that Pt is well-dispersed within the NiO or Ni0 nanoparticles, as further corroborated by the EDS linescans. For the calcined catalyst (Fig. 11a), a d-spacing of 0.24 nm was observed, characteristic of the (1 1 1) plane of the crystalline cubic (Fm3m) phase of NiO. This observation suggests that the presence of Pt did not alter significantly the structure of the NiO crystals in the calcined NiPt/12ZrS catalyst. The above could be due to a small Pt loading in the catalysts (theoretical Ni:Pt molar ratio ≈ 17:1). Conversely, for the reduced catalyst (Fig. 11b), a d-spacing of 0.20 nm was observed, associated with the (1 1 1) plane of the crystalline cubic (Fm3m) phase of metallic Ni0. In this case, Pt was distributed in the reduced Ni phase, but again without altering its crystalline structure. No non-reduced NiO nanoparticles were identified in the NiPt/12ZrS sample after the reduction treatment (Fig. 11b). The TEM images of the reduced catalysts and their respective relative frequency histograms of particle size are presented in Fig. 12. All the catalysts exhibited the cylindrical mesopore structure of SBA-15, wherein the supported NiPt nanoparticles were observed as dark spots. According to the relative frequency histograms, the NiPt/S catalysts demonstrated the largest average particle size compared to those of the NiPt/xZrS catalysts. Thus, the average size of metal nanoparticles changed in the following order: NiPt/8ZrS (6.4 nm) < NiPt/4ZrS (7.9 nm) < NiPt/12ZrS (8.4 nm) < NiPt/S (11.8 nm). This observation suggests that ZrO2 promotes the dispersion of metallic NiPt nanoparticles in the NiPt/xZrS catalysts, leading to smaller particle sizes with narrower distributions, which could be due to the stronger metal-support interaction in the zirconia-containing catalysts [28]. The dispersion of bimetallic NiPt nanoparticles in the reduced catalysts was estimated based on the average size of metal nanoparticles determined by TEM, as it was proposed previously for supported metal catalysts [42,43]. For the calculation of metal dispersion (D), Eq. 3 was used, where d M at. is the atomic diameter of the metal and d M is the average particle size of the metal nanoparticle in the reduced catalyst [43]. (3) D = 5.01 ∙ d M ⁢ at . d M × 100 % , when ⁢ d M > 6 ⁢ nm In our work, instead of monometallic Ni nanoparticles, bimetallic NiPt nanoparticles were obtained (HAADF-STEM characterization, Fig. 11b), but their structural characteristics were very close to those of monometallic Ni nanoparticles due to a very low Pt loading in the catalysts (theoretical Ni:Pt molar ratio ≈ 17:1). As showed by XPS and SEM-EDS, Ni and Pt species were distributed homogeneously on the surface and in the bulk of bimetallic nanoparticles maintaining the Ni:Pt molar ratio close to the theoretical one. In addition, for all the catalysts, the average size of bimetallic nanoparticles was larger than 6 nm (Fig. 12). Therefore, for the estimation of the dispersion of bimetallic NiPt nanoparticles, the same equation was used, but with the atomic diameter d M at . of 0.250 nm, estimated as the mean value of atomic diameters of 17 Ni atoms (0.248 nm) and 1 Pt atom (0.278 nm) forming bimetallic nanoparticles, and d M being the average particle size of bimetallic NiPt nanoparticles determined by TEM (for more details see section S1, Supplementary Material). The obtained results for dispersion are: NiPt/8ZrS (19.6 %) > NiPt/4ZrS (15.9 %) > NiPt/12ZrS (14.9 %) > NiPt/S (10.6 %), being as expected, the higher dispersion for catalysts with smaller particle size. An interesting observation is that average particle size and dispersion are not directly proportional to the ZrO2 loading in the catalysts, reaching their minimum and maximum values, respectively, for the NiPt/8ZrS catalyst. Further increase in zirconia loading in the NiPt/12ZrS catalyst leads to an increase in the average particle size and a decrease in metal dispersion. This is probably due to a lower surface area of the 12ZrS support because of a high ZrO2 loading in the support (Table 1). 3.2 Hydrodeoxygenation of anisole 3.2.1 Catalytic activity and selectivity Catalytic activity tests were performed in the HDO of anisole. Anisole was selected as one of the most simple model compounds representative of bio-oil obtained by quick pyrolysis. Anisole conversions obtained with reduced NiPt/xZrS catalysts are presented in Fig. 13. All the catalysts exhibited activity for anisole transformation upon selected reaction conditions (250 °C, 6.8 MPa total H2 pressure) giving final anisole conversions of about 98–99 % at 6 h reaction time. The highest conversion (99.3 %) was achieved with the NiPt/8ZrS catalyst. At lower reaction times (0.25 h to 3 h), differences in the reaction rates were more noticeable, being the NiPt/8ZrS catalyst more active than other samples. The distributions of the main liquid products are presented in Fig. 14. Among the reaction products, cyclohexyl methyl ether (CME), cyclohexanol (CHL), and cyclohexane (CHA) were detected. Traces (< 1 %) of methyl cyclopentane (MCP) as the isomerization of CHA product and 1,1’-byciclohexyl (BCH) as the condensation product were also observed. CME is a product of the hydrogenation of the aromatic rings of anisole on the metal active sites, and it is the principal reaction product for the NiPt/S catalyst due to its lack of acidity. CHL was produced in smaller amounts (between 1.2 % and 2.7 %) than CME, and its concentration passed through the maximum almost at the same reaction time as the concentration of CME (Fig. 14). This result points to the formation of CME and CHL in parallel reaction routes and not in a consecutive transformation of anisole to CME and then of CME to CHL. On the other hand, for the NiPt/xZrS catalysts, as the reaction time increased, the fraction of CME in the products decreased, whereas the amount of CHA increased. This indicates a consecutive reaction pathway, in which first the aromatic ring of anisole is hydrogenated on metal active sites producing CME, with the following deoxygenation of the obtained CME intermediate to CHA by the participation of both the acid active sites provided by ZrO2 and the metal active sites of NiPt [44]. Among the examined catalysts, the NiPt/12ZrS produced the most of the fully hydrogenated and deoxygenated CHA product, as shown in Fig. 14d and is corroborated by its highest selectivity for CHA (S CHA) ( Table 4). Product distributions shown in Fig. 14 were used to determine initial reaction rates of formation of cyclohexyl methyl ether and cyclohexane products, (r CME)0 and (r CHA)0, Table 4. It was found that the rate of formation of CME slightly increased with the incorporation of 4 and 8 wt% of zirconia in the SBA-15 support, in line with an increase in the dispersion of bimetallic nanoparticles in these catalysts. On the other hand, the initial rate of CHA formation presented a much larger increase (in 10 times) for the NiPt/12ZrS catalyst compared to the NiPt/S analog. The above change in the deoxygenation ability of the catalysts cannot be attributed only to an increment in metal dispersion, which is much smaller. It seems to be in good accordance with an increase in the surface density of acid sites in the catalysts induced by zirconia’s presence. Thus, the density of acid sites increased from 0.12 µmol NH3/m2 for the NiPt/S catalyst to 1.32 µmol NH3/m2 for the NiPt/12ZrS one (in 11 times) being this increase of the same order as the increment of the initial rate of CHA formation. Finally, a comparison can be made between anisole conversion and selectivity to CHA obtained with bimetallic NiPt/xZrS catalysts in the present work and previously published literature data. Thus, the 0.5 % Pt/HY catalyst tested in the HDO of anisole at 250 °C and 4 MPa pressure gave anisole conversion of 85 % with 85.6 % selectivity to cyclohexane [45]. On the other hand, Pt x Ni5 (5 wt% Ni, 0.1–2 wt% Pt) catalysts supported on SBA-15 silica, evaluated in the HDO of anisole at 280 °C and 7.3 MPa pressure, resulted in higher anisole conversion (95.5–100.0 %), but lower selectivity to CHA (37–78 %) [13]. The above results indicate that the activity and selectivity of the catalysts synthesized in our study are similar or better than those of previously reported samples. 3.2.2 Kinetic fitting The performance of the NiPt/S and NiPt/xZrS catalysts in the HDO of anisole was analyzed with the help of kinetic analysis considering the simplified reaction mechanism: AN → k 1 OXY → k 2 CHA In this reaction mechanism, in the first step, anisole (AN) is converted to the oxygenated intermediate compounds CME and CHL, where OXY is their sum (OXY = CME + CHL). For this step, the main reaction is hydrogenation of the aromatic ring of anisole on metal active sites, while both types of active sites (metal and acid) participate in the transformation of anisole to CHL by a hydrogenation/demethylation process. In the second step, OXY compounds are deoxygenated to cyclohexane (CHA). In this step, both the metal and the acid active sites participate, but the acid sites are more important since in the absence of acidity (NiPt/S catalyst) this step does not occur. A similar simplified reaction mechanism was proposed previously [15]. The reaction rate equations corresponding to the above reaction mechanism are given in Eqs. 4–6: (4) − d C AN dt = k 1 C AN (5) d C OXY dt = k 1 C AN − k 2 C OXY (6) d C CHA dt = k 2 C O X Y The pseudo-first order reaction rate coefficients (k 1 and k 2) were determined utilizing the least-squares method and the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm implemented in the lsqcurvefit function in MATLAB (2024b). This methodology involves fitting the experimental data to the simplified reaction mechanism model described by Eqs. 4–6 by minimizing the sum of the squared residuals between the experimental data points and model predictions. The Eqs. 4–6 were solved using the 5th order Runge-Kutta method (for more details see section S2 and Fig. S1, Supplementary Material). The optimized k 1 and k 2 values are presented in Table 4. The k 1 constant corresponds to the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring of AN. The highest k 1 value was obtained for the NiPt/8ZrS (3.14 h–1), followed by the NiPt/4ZrS (2.32 h–1), and NiPt/12ZrS (1.87 h–1). These values of k 1 are higher than those reported previously for the 4 %Ni/M-SBA-15 catalysts with M = Ti, Zr, Al or Nb (k 1 = 1.3 – 1.7 h−1) [15], and obtained for the 5 %Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts with varying Si/Al molar ratios in the Al-MCM-41 supports (k 1 = 1.19 – 1.80 h−1) [46]. In both cited works, the HDO of anisole was performed at higher temperature (280 °C) and 4.8 MPa total pressure [15,46]. These results indicate that the addition of Pt to the catalysts results in an enhancement of their activity in the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring of anisole. The k 2 constant corresponds to the deoxygenation of oxygenated intermediate compounds (CME + CHL) to produce CHA. The k 2 values increased with increasing the amount of grafted ZrO2 in the supports, from 0.02 to 1.39 h–1 for NiPt/S and NiPt/12ZrS, respectively, which was attributed to the progressive increase in acidity of the catalysts with ZrO2 incorporation into the SBA-15 supports. The estimated values of k 1 and k 2 correlate with the characteristics of the metal and acid active phases in the catalysts ( Fig. 15). This result could be expected based on the previous suppositions about participation of different types of active sites in different reaction steps. The k 1 values demonstrated a good correlation with the dispersion of metal particles in the reduced catalysts estimated from the average particle sizes determined by TEM. Namely, k 1 increases with increasing metal dispersion (Fig. 15a). The rate constant k 2, associated with the deoxygenation of oxygenated intermediates (CME and CHL), exhibits a trend with the surface density of acid sites (the total amount of acid sites per m2 of catalyst surface) measured by NH3-TPD (Fig. 15b), demonstrating that the acid sites provided by the grafted ZrO2 are essential for facilitating Caliphatic-O bond cleavage and the deoxygenation process using NiPt/xZrS catalysts. On the other hand, the metal active sites also participate in the deoxygenation step of the reaction. Therefore, the obtained results indicate that the proximity of the metal and acid sites in the catalysts is another important factor for the efficient deoxygenation of OXY intermediates. Thus, the NiPt/12ZrS catalyst with the highest surface density of acid sites should have a larger number of acid sites close to the metal nanoparticles, making their behavior in deoxygenation more efficient. This result illustrates that the surface density of acid sites, as well as metal dispersion, is an important characteristic of bifunctional metal-acid catalysts for HDO. Finally, summarizing the results from the characterization of the metal active phase and acid properties of the NiPt catalysts supported on ZrO2-containing SBA-15 supports, it can be concluded that the role of zirconia in these catalytic systems is dual: on the one hand, a stronger metal-support interaction improves metal dispersion in the reduced catalysts and, on the other hand, ZrO2 introduces acidity to the catalysts, being the acid and metal active sites in close proximity one to another. This could be the reason of metal-acid synergy in these catalysts. 3.2.3 Stability of the NiPt/8ZrS catalyst To evaluate the stability of the NiPt catalyst supported on ZrO2-grafted SBA-15, the most active NiPt/8ZrS catalyst was tested in three consecutive HDO reactions of anisole at 250 °C and 6.8 MPa pressure ( Fig. 16a). After each reaction, the used catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture via centrifugation and washed three times with heptane, without any additional regeneration process. The anisole conversion profiles shown in Fig. 16a indicate a slight decrease in anisole conversions in the first and second recycling of the NiPt/8ZrS catalyst (reactions 2 and 3). However, this could probably be due to some loss of the catalyst’s mass during separation and recycling ( Table 5). Nevertheless, in all the tests, consistent values of ∼99 % of anisole conversion were achieved at final reaction time (6 h). The rate constants k 1, expressed in h−1, showed a progressive decrease from 3.14 to 2.03 h−1. However, when these values were normalized per gram of catalyst, they showed similar values of k 1’ (31.4, 31.2, and 28.0 h−1 gcat −1 for the first, second and third reactions, respectively), indicating that the catalyst maintained almost constant performance in hydrogenation of anisole to CME. The above results demonstrate that the metal active sites of the NiPt/8ZrS catalyst were almost not affected in repeated catalytic cycles. On the other hand, the selectivity to cyclohexane notoriously decreased in the third reaction (Fig. 16b), giving S CHA value of about 27.0 %. In line with this, the values of the rate constant k 2 also decreased, even when they were normalized per gram of the catalyst (k2 ’, Table 5). This almost six-fold decrease from 4.6 to 0.8 h−1 gcat −1 suggests a reduction in the deoxygenation ability of the NiPt/8ZrS catalyst upon repeated use. Since the deoxygenation of CME and CHL to CHA requires participation of the active acid sites, in addition to the metallic ones, the above selectivity changes indicate deactivation of acid sites, presumably caused by deposition of soft coke or adsorption of organic compounds, as it was suggested previously [47–49]. Therefore, regeneration treatment should be considered for the acid sites to avoid selectivity loss in catalyst recycling. 4 Conclusions In the present work, the synthesis, characterization, and evaluation of the NiPt/xZrS catalysts in the HDO of anisole were performed. Elemental mapping confirmed the uniform distribution of grafted ZrO2 on the SBA-15 surface, with ZrO2 loadings close to the expected theoretical values. The Ni and Pt loadings in the calcined catalysts agreed with the nominal values and the metals were uniformly distributed on the supports. ZrO2 incorporation in SBA-15 did not alter the shape of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the supports, but decreased N2 uptake, S BET values and pore diameter with increasing ZrO2 loading, indicating obstruction of the mesopores by the deposited zirconia species. Ni and Pt impregnation further reduced the specific textural characteristics and pore diameter of the materials. The XRD patterns revealed the presence of the NiO crystalline phase in the calcined catalysts, which transforms to metallic Ni0 after reduction. According to the size of NiO (XRD) and metallic Ni nanoparticles (TEM), dispersion of Ni species on the ZrO2-containing supports was better than on unmodified SBA-15 silica due to a stronger metal-support interaction. In addition, ZrO2 incorporation increased the acidity of the catalysts. All the catalysts showed high activity in anisole transformation upon the selected reaction conditions, achieving the highest anisole conversion (99.3 %) and the best selectivity to CHA (95.8 %) with the NiPt/8ZrS and NiPt/12ZrS catalysts, respectively. The reaction rate constants k 1 and k 2 showed good correlation with the metal particle dispersion and catalysts’ acidity, respectively, which confirm the participation of metal and acid active sites at different steps of anisole HDO. Repeated catalytic tests performed with the most active NiPt/8ZrS catalyst showed preservation of the catalytic performance of the metal active sites, while the performance of the acid active sites was affected probably due to coke deposition or adsorption of organic compounds decreasing selectivity to cyclohexane product. Finally, it was shown that the role of zirconia in the NiPt/xZrS catalysts consisted in both an increase in metal dispersion due to stronger metal-support interaction and the introduction of acid sites in the catalyst giving it a bifunctional metal-acid character, which is important for some catalytic applications such as hydrodeoxygenation. coredata.dc:description: ZrO2-SBA-15 supports were synthesized by chemical grafting and used to prepare NiPt catalysts tested in the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole. ZrO2 loading in the supports was varied (4, 8, and 12 wt% of ZrO2) maintaining the metal loading constant (5 wt% Ni, 1 wt% Pt) with the aim to inquire into the effect of ZrO2 on the characteristics and performance of the NiPt/Zr-SBA-15 catalysts. A simplified reaction mechanism was proposed and kinetic analysis was performed to estimate reaction rate constants and correlate them with characteristics of the active sites. ZrO2-containing catalysts showed a better dispersion of metal nanoparticles than the reference NiPt/SBA-15 due to a stronger metal-support interaction and increased acidity. Both hydrogenation and deoxygenation abilities of the catalysts (rate constants k 1 and k 2 ) improved with zirconia addition. The effect of zirconia was much stronger on the increased deoxygenation of cyclohexyl methyl ether and cyclohexanol to cyclohexane, in line with increasing surface density of acid sites. The hydrogenation ability of the catalysts correlated well with metal dispersion. Thus, the role of zirconia in the NiPt/Zr-SBA-15 catalysts was clarified by using a kinetic approach. The participation of metal and acid sites at different steps of anisole HDO and the reasons of metal-acid synergy in these bifunctional catalysts were demonstrated. The stability of the most active NiPt/8ZrS catalyst was tested in three repeated catalytic cycles. The metallic active sites showed stability in recycling, while the acid active sites were affected by coke deposition or adsorption of organic compounds decreasing selectivity to cyclohexane product.
